item.title: Shivani Blog Post
item.description: Hi this is my very first blog post and I will be talking about something new I learned about R! Using the reticulate package in R will allow you to go back and forth with R interface using python. This makes it a super flexible and efficient feature! Link to project 1 Link to google

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: Data Wrangling and Data Exploration Introduction ### Intro Packages and Data library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(ggplot2) library(tibble) library(readr) Sanitation <- read_csv("/stor/home/sm44452/Project/Sanitation.csv") Country_information <- read_csv("/stor/home/sm44452/Project/Country_information.csv") The data sets I have chosen for this project contains various information for countries in the year of 2017 relating to access to sanitized water and country statistics. The first data set called Country_information has 4 variables: Country, Region, Surface Area(km), and Population(in thousands). The data was acquired online from a website called Kaggle.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: Shivani Madhav sm44452 Introduction 0. Introduce your dataset and each of your variables (or just your main variables if you have lots) in a paragraph. What are they measuring? How many observations? winequality <- read_csv('/stor/home/sm44452/Project/winequality.csv') winequalityN <- read_csv('/stor/home/sm44452/Project/winequalityN.csv') library(lmtest) library(sandwich) library(plotROC) library(tidyverse) library(MASS) library(glmnet) library(ggplot2) winequality %>% na.omit() ## # A tibble: 6,469 x 9 ## type volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides density pH sulphates alcohol ## <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 white 0.
